name.text: 10.1.2.4 Multiplying one complex number by another

questiontext.text:
Multiplying complex numbers

In multiplication we proceed using an obvious approach: again consider any two complex numbers \(z=a+i b\) and \(w=c+i d\). Then \[\begin{aligned} zw&=(a+i b)(c+i d)\\ &=ac+aid+ibc+i^2bd\qquad\end{aligned}\] obtained in the usual way by multiplying all the terms in one bracket by all the terms in the other bracket. Now we use the fundamental relation \(i^2=-1\) so that \[\begin{aligned} zw&=ac+ai d+i bc-bd\\ &=ac-bd+i(ad+bc)\qquad\end{aligned}\] where we have re-grouped terms with the ‘\(i\)’ symbol and terms without the ‘\(i\)’ symbol separately. These are the real and imaginary parts of the product \(zw\) respectively. A numerical example will confirm the approach. If \(z=2-3i\) and \(w=-4+2i\) then \[\begin{aligned} zw&=(2-3i)(-4+2i)\\ &=2(-4)+2(2i)-3i(-4)-3i(2i)\qquad\\ &=-8+4i+12i-6i^2\\ &=-8+16i+6\\ &=-2+16i\end{aligned}\]
